questions.question_text_1: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : SOFTWARE ENGINEERING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)
question_texts: THIS IS QUESTION PAPER FOR THE SUBJECT "DEGREE LEVEL : SOFTWARE ENGINEERING (COMPUTER BASED EXAM)" ARE YOU SURE YOU HAVE TO WRITE EXAM FOR THIS SUBJECT? CROSS CHECK YOUR HALL TICKET TO CONFIRM THE SUBJECTS TO BE WRITTEN. (IF IT IS NOT THE CORRECT SUBJECT, PLS CHECK THE SECTION AT THE TOP FOR THE SUBJECTS REGISTERED BY YOU)

questions.question_text_1:
You're tasked with building a digital wallet feature for an e-commerce platform. Your team suggests directly looking into how similar apps like Paytm and PhonePe work. 
Which of the following best describes the activity being performed?
question_texts:
You're tasked with building a digital wallet feature for an e-commerce platform. Your team suggests directly looking into how similar apps like Paytm and PhonePe work. 
Which of the following best describes the activity being performed?

questions.question_text_1:
You are developing an online education platform. Professors use the system to upload materials, students access the content, and the university’s accreditation body occasionally reviews course reports generated from the system. 
Which of the following correctly categorizes the stakeholders?
question_texts:
You are developing an online education platform. Professors use the system to upload materials, students access the content, and the university’s accreditation body occasionally reviews course reports generated from the system. 
Which of the following correctly categorizes the stakeholders?

options.option_text: Professors – Primary users; Students – Secondary users; Accreditation body –Tertiary users
Professors – Secondary users; Students – Primary users; Accreditation body –Tertiary users
Professors – Primary users; Students – Primary users; Accreditation body –Tertiary users
Professors – Tertiary users; Students – Secondary users; Accreditation body –Primary users

questions.question_text_1:
One stakeholder wants user passwords to expire every 30 days. Another insists users must not be forced to change passwords more than once a year. 
What kind of requirement issue is this?
question_texts:
One stakeholder wants user passwords to expire every 30 days. Another insists users must not be forced to change passwords more than once a year. 
What kind of requirement issue is this?

options.option_text: Working software is the primary measure of progress
Processes and tools over individuals and interactions
Following a plan over responding to change

questions.question_text_1:
While designing the seller portal's financial features, your team needs to comply with local banking regulations on fund transfers. You refer to official banking policies and competitor portal FAQs. 
Which requirement gathering technique does this illustrate?
question_texts:
While designing the seller portal's financial features, your team needs to comply with local banking regulations on fund transfers. You refer to official banking policies and competitor portal FAQs. 
Which requirement gathering technique does this illustrate?

questions.question_text_1:
A startup is developing an app for food delivery. They’ve created clickable images of app screens using PowerPoint and ask users to try placing a test order. 
What kind of prototype is being used?
question_texts:
A startup is developing an app for food delivery. They’ve created clickable images of app screens using PowerPoint and ask users to try placing a test order. 
What kind of prototype is being used?

questions.question_text_1:
A Scrum team has assigned point values to each user story. In their first sprint, they completed 2 stories totaling 5 points. 
What is the estimated velocity of the team?
question_texts:
A Scrum team has assigned point values to each user story. In their first sprint, they completed 2 stories totaling 5 points. 
What is the estimated velocity of the team?

questions.question_text_1:
A company develops a mobile game for low-end devices. During design, the team restricts image resolution and optimizes memory usage by reusing textures. 
Which quality of good design is being prioritized here?
question_texts:
A company develops a mobile game for low-end devices. During design, the team restricts image resolution and optimizes memory usage by reusing textures. 
Which quality of good design is being prioritized here?

questions.question_text_1:
A programmer is working with a third-party Python API for image processing. Their code compiles, but the output image is not what they expected. They cannot see or change the library’s internal code. 
Which debugging technique should they use?
question_texts:
A programmer is working with a third-party Python API for image processing. Their code compiles, but the output image is not what they expected. They cannot see or change the library’s internal code. 
Which debugging technique should they use?

options.option_text: Step into each function using PDB
Forward debugging to trace internal logic
Black box debugging using documentation and examples
Dump and diff comparison between images

questions.question_text_1: A file-sharing system allows users to both download and upload files from / to other users without relying on any central server. Each user system shares a part of their storage. What architecture is being described?
question_texts: A file-sharing system allows users to both download and upload files from / to other users without relying on any central server. Each user system shares a part of their storage. What architecture is being described?

questions.question_text_1: Your team developed a system over 12 months using a strict sequential process. After the final release, the client expresses dissatisfaction due to misunderstood requirements. What was the likely development model?
question_texts: Your team developed a system over 12 months using a strict sequential process. After the final release, the client expresses dissatisfaction due to misunderstood requirements. What was the likely development model?

questions.question_text_1: In an e-commerce system, the SellerModule calls a function in the InventoryModule using a variable operationFlag to decide whether to view, add, or delete a product. Which type of coupling is present?
question_texts: In an e-commerce system, the SellerModule calls a function in the InventoryModule using a variable operationFlag to decide whether to view, add, or delete a product. Which type of coupling is present?

questions.question_text_1:
In an online seller portal, the Seller class uses the Inventory class’s viewInventory(sellerID) method to fetch the list of products. Additionally, the Inventory class implements an interface InventoryInterface that defines standard inventory operations. 
Which of the following relationships can be identified from this scenario?
question_texts:
In an online seller portal, the Seller class uses the Inventory class’s viewInventory(sellerID) method to fetch the list of products. Additionally, the Inventory class implements an interface InventoryInterface that defines standard inventory operations. 
Which of the following relationships can be identified from this scenario?

options.option_text: Seller and Inventory have an inheritance relationship
Seller and Inventory have an association relationship
Inventory and InventoryInterface have a dependency relationship
Seller and InventoryInterface have a composition relationship

questions.question_text_1: A team is designing a new tax filing software for first-time users. Which of the following features would most likely improve the learnability of their system?
question_texts: A team is designing a new tax filing software for first-time users. Which of the following features would most likely improve the learnability of their system?

options.option_text: Step-by-step wizard that guides users through each section
Ability to undo recent entries using a shortcut
Templates for common user profiles (e.g., salaried, freelancer)
Strong password requirement with special characters and numbers

questions.question_text_1: In a distributed software development environment, why is it important to define interfaces clearly before implementing components?
question_texts: In a distributed software development environment, why is it important to define interfaces clearly before implementing components?

options.option_text: It ensures that all teams use the same programming language forimplementation.
It helps maintain consistent communication between components developedby different team members.
It allows the internal implementation of a component to change withoutaffecting others.
It eliminates the need for documentation, since the code is self-explanatory.

questions.question_text_1:
A module in your project depends on a third-party payment gateway. During testing, you discover it is not functioning properly due to a known bug in the vendor’s code. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts:
A module in your project depends on a third-party payment gateway. During testing, you discover it is not functioning properly due to a known bug in the vendor’s code. 
Based on the above data, answer the given subquestions.

question_texts: What is the most suitable way to mitigate the risk described in the scenario?

options.option_text: Increase the project budget to cover delays
Benchmark and conduct regular inspections of third-party components
Ask developers to avoid using third-party modules altogether

props.summary:
### Summary of Core Topics, Concepts, Principles, and Equations

#### 1. **Software Development Methodologies**
- **Agile Methodology**: Emphasizes customer collaboration, responding to change, and iterative development.
- **Waterfall Model**: Sequential development process with distinct phases.
- **Spiral Model**: Combines iterative development with systematic aspects of the waterfall model.
- **Prototype Model**: Involves creating prototypes early in the development process.

#### 2. **Requirements Analysis**
- **Stakeholder Analysis**: Identifying and categorizing stakeholders (primary, secondary, tertiary).
- **Requirement Gathering Techniques**: Documentation, interviews, focus groups, observation.
- **SMART Criteria**: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound.
- **Requirement Issues**: Incomplete, ambiguous, inconsistent, implicit requirements.

#### 3. **Software Design Principles**
- **SOLID Principles**:
  - **Single Responsibility Principle**: A class should have only one reason to change.
  - **Interface Segregation Principle**: Clients should not be forced to depend on methods they do not use.
  - **Open-Closed Principle**: Software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.
  - **Liskov Substitution Principle**: Objects should be replaceable with instances of their subtypes without altering the correctness of the program.
  - **Dependency Inversion Principle**: High-level modules should not depend on low-level modules but on abstractions.

- **Design Patterns**:
  - **Facade Pattern**: Provides a simplified interface to a complex subsystem.
  - **Adapter Pattern**: Allows incompatible interfaces to work together.
  - **Builder Design Pattern**: Separates the construction of a complex object from its representation.
  - **Strategy Design Pattern**: Defines a family of algorithms, encapsulates each one, and makes them interchangeable.

#### 4. **Software Quality Attributes**
- **Learnability**: Ease with which new users can learn to use the system.
- **Efficiency**: Optimizing resource usage (e.g., memory, processing power).
- **Maintainability**: Ease with which a system can be modified to correct faults, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.
- **Understandability**: Ease with which the system can be understood by developers and users.

#### 5. **Software Testing and Debugging**
- **Cyclomatic Complexity**: Measures the complexity of a program by counting the number of linearly independent paths.
- **Debugging Techniques**: Black box debugging, white box debugging, step-by-step debugging.

#### 6. **Software Architecture**
- **Client-Server Architecture**: Separates the client (user interface) from the server (data processing).
- **Peer-to-Peer (P2P) Architecture**: Decentralized architecture where each node can act as both a client and a server.
- **Model-View-Controller (MVC)**: Separates the application into three interconnected components.
- **Pipe and Filter Architecture**: Processes data through a series of filters.

#### 7. **Coupling and Cohesion**
- **Coupling**: Degree of interdependence between software modules.
  - **Control Coupling**: When one module controls the flow of another module.
  - **Content Coupling**: When one module directly modifies or relies on the internal workings of another module.
  - **Data Coupling**: When modules share data through parameters.
  - **Common Coupling**: When modules share a common data area.

- **Cohesion**: Degree to which the elements inside a module belong together.

#### 8. **Prototyping**
- **Storyboard**: Visual representation of the user interface and interactions.
- **Paper Prototype**: Low-fidelity prototype created using paper and pencil.
- **Digital Mock-up**: High-fidelity prototype created using digital tools.
- **Interactive Prototype**: Functional prototype that allows user interaction.

#### 9. **Risk Management**
- **Technical Risk**: Risks related to the technical aspects of the project.
- **Business Risk**: Risks related to the business aspects of the project.
- **Project Risk**: Risks related to the project management aspects.
- **Legal Risk**: Risks related to legal aspects of the project.

#### 10. **Effort Estimation**
- **COCOMO Model**: Constructive Cost Model for estimating the effort required to develop software.
  - **Organic Project**: \( \text{Effort} = 2.4 \times (\text{KLOC})^{1.05} \)
  - **Semi-detached Project**: \( \text{Effort} = 3.0 \times (\text{KLOC})^{1.12} \)
  - **Embedded Project**: \( \text{Effort} = 3.6 \times (\text{KLOC})^{1.20} \)

- **Cost Drivers**: Factors that influence the effort required to develop software (e.g., required reliability, database size, application experience, language and tool experience).

### Knowledge Graph 

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Software Development Methodologies] --> B[Agile]
    A --> C[Waterfall]
    A --> D[Spiral]
    A --> E[Prototype]
    B --> F[Customer Collaboration]
    B --> G[Iterative Development]
    C --> H[Sequential Phases]
    D --> I[Iterative Development]
    D --> J[Systematic Aspects]
    E --> K[Early Prototypes]

    L[Requirements Analysis] --> M[Stakeholder Analysis]
    L --> N[Requirement Gathering Techniques]
    L --> O[SMART Criteria]
    L --> P[Requirement Issues]
    M --> Q[Primary Stakeholders]
    M --> R[Secondary Stakeholders]
    M --> S[Tertiary Stakeholders]
    N --> T[Documentation]
    N --> U[Interviews]
    N --> V[Focus Groups]
    N --> W[Observation]
    O --> X[Specific]
    O --> Y[Measurable]
    O --> Z[Achievable]
    O --> AA[Relevant]
    O --> AB[Time-bound]
    P --> AC[Incomplete]
    P --> AD[Ambiguous]
    P --> AE[Inconsistent]
    P --> AF[Implicit]

    AG[Software Design Principles] --> AH[SOLID Principles]
    AG --> AI[Design Patterns]
    AH --> AJ[Single Responsibility Principle]
    AH --> AK[Interface Segregation Principle]
    AH --> AL[Open-Closed Principle]
    AH --> AM[Liskov Substitution Principle]
    AH --> AN[Dependency Inversion Principle]
    AI --> AO[Facade Pattern]
    AI --> AP[Adapter Pattern]
    AI --> AQ[Builder Design Pattern]
    AI --> AR[Strategy Design Pattern]

    AS[Software Quality Attributes] --> AT[Learnability]
    AS --> AU[Efficiency]
    AS --> AV[Maintainability]
    AS --> AW[Understandability]

    AX[Software Testing and Debugging] --> AY[Cyclomatic Complexity]
    AX --> AZ[Debugging Techniques]
    AY --> BA[Linearly Independent Paths]
    AZ --> BB[Black Box Debugging]
    AZ --> BC[White Box Debugging]
    AZ --> BD[Step-by-Step Debugging]

    BE[Software Architecture] --> BF[Client-Server Architecture]
    BE --> BG[Peer-to-Peer Architecture]
    BE --> BH[Model-View-Controller]
    BE --> BI[Pipe and Filter Architecture]

    BJ[Coupling and Cohesion] --> BK[Control Coupling]
    BJ --> BL[Content Coupling]
    BJ --> BM[Data Coupling]
    BJ --> BN[Common Coupling]
    BJ --> BO[Cohesion]

    BP[Prototyping] --> BQ[Storyboard]
    BP --> BR[Paper Prototype]
    BP --> BS[Digital Mock-up]
    BP --> BT[Interactive Prototype]

    BU[Risk Management] --> BV[Technical Risk]
    BU --> BW[Business Risk]
    BU --> BX[Project Risk]
    BU --> BY[Legal Risk]

    BZ[Effort Estimation] --> CA[COCOMO Model]
    BZ --> CB[Cost Drivers]
    CA --> CC[Organic Project]
    CA --> CD[Semi-detached Project]
    CA --> CE[Embedded Project]
    CB --> CF[Required Reliability]
    CB --> CG[Database Size]
    CB --> CH[Application Experience]
    CB --> CI[Language and Tool Experience]
```

This knowledge graph visually maps the relationships between the core topics, concepts, principles, and equations essential for the exam.
